content:
TRUE. The statement is factually correct [1][2]. The Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet jointly awarded the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to Drs. Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman for their foundational discoveries concerning "nucleoside base modifications" [3][4]. This "chemical tweak" to messenger RNA (mRNA) was the critical breakthrough that enabled the rapid development of effective mRNA vaccines against COVID-19 [5][6].

## Award and Recipients

On October 2, 2023, the Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet in Stockholm, Sweden, announced that the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded jointly to Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman [4][7]. Katalin Karikó is a Hungarian-American biochemist affiliated with Szeged University in Hungary and is a senior vice president at BioNTech [8][9][en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine]. Drew Weissman is an American physician-scientist at the University of Pennsylvania's Perelman School of Medicine, where he is the Roberts Family Professor in Vaccine Research [10][8].

The two laureates shared the prize money of 11 million Swedish kronor (approximately $1 million USD) [7]. The official prize citation states the award was "for their discoveries concerning nucleoside base modifications that enabled the development of effective mRNA vaccines against COVID-19" [2][3][5].

## The Scientific Breakthrough: "Nucleoside Base Modifications"

The core of Karikó and Weissman's Nobel-winning work was solving a fundamental problem that had long hindered the therapeutic use of mRNA: lab-made mRNA was highly inflammatory and unstable, making it unsuitable for use in the human body [12][13].

### The Problem with Unmodified mRNA
When the researchers began their collaboration at the University of Pennsylvania, they observed that in vitro transcribed (lab-made) mRNA was recognized by the immune system's dendritic cells as a foreign substance [2]. This recognition triggered a strong and undesirable inflammatory response, releasing signaling molecules that could be harmful [14][2]. This immune reaction also led to inefficient production of the protein encoded by the mRNA, defeating its therapeutic purpose [14][5].

### The Discovery of a "Chemical Tweak"
Karikó and Weissman hypothesized that the reason lab-made mRNA provoked an immune reaction was its lack of chemical modifications, which are frequently present in RNA from mammalian cells [2][14]. They investigated this by creating different versions of mRNA, each with unique chemical alterations to its nucleoside bases (the "letters" A, U, G, and C of the genetic code) [2][14].

Their seminal 2005 paper, published in the journal *Immunity*, revealed a striking result: when the nucleoside base uridine (U) was replaced with a modified version, such as pseudouridine (Ψ), the inflammatory response was almost completely abolished [2][15][16]. This modification allowed the synthetic mRNA to evade recognition by innate immune sensors called Toll-like receptors (TLRs), particularly TLR7 and TLR8 [17][18].

### Dual Benefits of the Modification
Subsequent research by the pair in 2008 and 2010 further demonstrated that these base modifications had a second crucial benefit: they markedly increased protein production compared to unmodified mRNA [2][19]. This was because the modified mRNA avoided activating an enzyme known as PKR, which would otherwise shut down protein synthesis [2][18]. Together, these discoveries eliminated the primary obstacles to the clinical application of mRNA technology [19].

## Impact on COVID-19 Vaccine Development

The discoveries made by Karikó and Weissman fundamentally changed the scientific understanding of how mRNA interacts with the immune system [2][20]. Though their key findings were published over a decade before the COVID-19 pandemic, they provided the essential blueprint for creating safe and effective mRNA vaccines [19][2].

When the pandemic began in early 2020, this technology—licensed by companies like BioNTech and Moderna—allowed for the development of vaccines at an unprecedented rate [9][2]. These vaccines, which use nucleoside-modified mRNA to instruct cells to build the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and train the immune system, were approved by December 2020 [21]. The Nobel Committee commended the laureates for their contribution to this rapid vaccine development, which has saved millions of lives, prevented severe disease, and allowed societies to reopen [8][21].
